title: Contributing to crvsreportpackage
text: new pull request created, subject peer review. review process follow guidelines set duck book. Reviewers follow series steps: Read understand ticket acceptance criteria. quick look GitHub pull request see changed. Update data code locally ensure testing right environment. Make sure branch. Run test suite ensure code conforms style guide. Run pipeline ensure functionality claims achieved. Throughout process reviewers write comments, using GitHub functionality usually good starting place. changes requested communication peers strongly encouraged. order standardise review process reviewers follow template bellow. ensure consistent feedback: merge approved, ticked closed relevant branch deleted. tech-debt associated ticket must spun-new tickets merge happens.
code: ##  Code review  #### Documentation  Any new code includes all the following forms of documentation:  - [ ] **Function Documentation** as docstrings within the function definition. - [ ] **Examples** demonstrating major functionality, which runs successfully locally.  #### Functionality  - [ ] **Installation**: Installation or build of the code succeeds. - [ ] **Functionality**: Any functional claims of new code have been confirmed. - [ ] **Automated tests**: Unit tests cover essential functions for a reasonable range   of inputs and conditions. All tests pass on your local machine. - [ ] **Packaging guidelines**: New code conforms to the project contribution   guidelines. ---  ### Review comments  *Insert detailed comments here!*  These might include, but not exclusively:  - bugs that need fixing (does it work as expected? and does it work with other code that it is likely to interact with?) - alternative methods (could it be written more efficiently or with more clarity?) - documentation improvements (does the documentation reflect how the code actually works?) - additional tests that should be implemented (do the tests effectively assure that it  works correctly?) - code style improvements (could the code be written more clearly?)  Your suggestions should be tailored to the code that you are reviewing. Be critical and clear, but not mean. Ask questions and set actions.

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Choropleth thematic maps visualise variation values variable across geographical areas encoding colour gradient. Alternative graphics bar lollipop chart used show data lack potentially important spatial information. choropleth map allows begin identify hotspot areas clusters high low values. However, three key issues consider choosing display data choropleth map. 1.Counts rates Choropleth maps visualise distribution counts sensitive population size. population distribution mapped rather variable interest. therefore recommended map rates percentages population risk accounted . 2.Modifiable Areal Unit Problem Modifiable Areal Unit Problem MAUP (Openshaw, 1984) points spatial distribution values choropleth map may function size shape geographical areas. much can MAUP need aware potential impact. 3.Classification schemes Different classification schemes can produce different choropleth maps (see ). distibution histogram sensitive size bins spatial distribution visualised choropleth map can affected intervals. good practice inspect values variable histogram deciding classification scheme adopt.

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: main package using create choropleth maps tmap package. install package can run: also using sf package load spatial data, RColorBrewer colour palettes dplyr data manipulation.
code: install.packages("tmap") library(tmap) library(sf) library(RColorBrewer) library(dplyr)

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Subnational administrative boundaries available two sources: GADM Natural Earth. data free use non-commercial purposes.

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: can either download administrative boundary files using geodata package directly GADM website. function gadm() two key arguments. need supply three-letter ISO code country choose level administrative subdivision. 0 value country 1 next administrative level . code loads states Nigeria. prefer download files manually website need select ‘Nigeria’ country dropdown choose file format. GeoJSON open, non-proprietary format used across Web. three administrative divisions available: 0 National 1 States (36 + Federal Capital Territory) 2 Local Government Areas (774) download ‘level 1’ GeoJSON format copying URL unzipping . can use st_read() function sf package load file R session. sf package converts GeoJSON file simple features object, data frame features stored rows attributes columns. feature geometries object stored list-column end. coordinates describe boundary state.
code: library(geodata) nigeria <- gadm(country = "NGA",  level = 1,  path = tempdir(), version = "latest") download.file("https://geodata.ucdavis.edu/gadm/gadm4.1/json/gadm41_NGA_1.json.zip",               "gadm41_NGA_1.json.zip") unzip("gadm41_NGA_1.json.zip") nigeria <- st_read("gadm41_NGA_1.json")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Level 1 administrative boundaries available Natural Earth using ne_states() function rnaturalearth package. can also download subnational boundaries directly Natural Earth website. scroll ‘Admin 1 – States, Provinces’ can download ESRI shapefile first-order administrative boundaries number countries. obtain states Nigeria need filter results ISO code.
code: library(rnaturalearth) nigeria <- ne_states(country = "nigeria", returnclass = "sf") download.file("https://www.naturalearthdata.com/http//www.naturalearthdata.com/download/10m/cultural/ne_10m_admin_1_states_provinces.zip", "ne_10m_admin_1_states_provinces.zip") unzip("ne_10m_admin_1_states_provinces.zip") nigeria <- st_read("ne_10m_admin_1_states_provinces.shp") |>    filter(adm0_a3 == "NGA")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: loading st_read(), R console prints number features, geometry type, dimensions, bounding box, coordinate reference system (CRS). can confirm 37 features (states) vector boundary layer projected World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84), longitude latitude units decimal degrees. can visualise state boundaries using base R plot() function. just need supply geometry column.
code: nigeria <- st_read("data/nigeria.geojson") #> Reading layer `nigeria' from data source  #>   `/home/runner/work/crvsreportpackage/crvsreportpackage/vignettes/data/nigeria.geojson'  #>   using driver `GeoJSON' #> Simple feature collection with 37 features and 1 field #> Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: 2.671082 ymin: 4.272162 xmax: 14.66994 ymax: 13.88029 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 plot(nigeria$geometry)

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: can also use tmap package plot state boundaries. Combining tm_shape() tm_borders() functions renders outlines state.
code: tm_shape(nigeria) +   tm_borders()

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: borders can styled passing col (colour) lwd (border line width) arguments tm_borders() function.
code: tm_shape(nigeria) +    tm_borders(col = "#000000", lwd = 0.5)

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: state can labelled using tm_text() function. , supply various arguments style labels. argument auto.placement ensures labels don’t sit top .  want label specific states can use filter.
code: tm_shape(nigeria) +    tm_borders(col = "#000000", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state",            size = 0.8,           col = "black",           auto.placement = TRUE) tm_shape(nigeria) +    tm_borders(col = "#000000", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_shape(nigeria |> filter(state %in% c("Federal Capital Territory","Jigawa","Lagos","Sokoto"))) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE)

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: boundaries state Nigeria need statistical data create choropleth map. using data provided 2021 Nigeria Multiple Indicators Cluster Survey (MICS) percentage children age 5 whose births registered Nigerian state. spatial data birth registration data share matching state variable can use join datasets. check state names consistent datasets can run anti join. can see ‘Federal Capital Territory’ spatial data match birth registration data. state recorded ‘FCT Abuja’ dataset. can fix recoding state name spatial data. can now run left_join() function join two datasets together. left_join() fails find match enters missing value corresponding row. can therefore check join worked filtering missing values. Now ready create choropleth map.
code: head(df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   state     percent #>   <chr>       <dbl> #> 1 Abia         66.8 #> 2 Adamawa      79.7 #> 3 Akwa Ibom    72.1 #> 4 Anambra      86.5 #> 5 Bauchi       38.3 #> 6 Bayelsa      28.2 anti_join(nigeria, df, by = "state") #> Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 1 field #> Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: 6.749594 ymin: 8.404707 xmax: 7.628196 ymax: 9.351419 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #>                       state                       geometry #> 1 Federal Capital Territory MULTIPOLYGON (((6.978107 8.... nigeria <- nigeria |>    mutate(state = case_when(     state == "Federal Capital Territory" ~ "FCT Abuja",     TRUE ~ state)     ) sf <- left_join(nigeria, df, by = "state") filter(sf, is.na(percent)) #> Simple feature collection with 0 features and 2 fields #> Bounding box:  xmin: NA ymin: NA xmax: NA ymax: NA #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> [1] state    percent  geometry #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: tm_polygons() function creates --shelf choropleth map. just supply name variable want visualise col title legend.  finer control choropleth map better use combination tm_borders() tm_fill(). allows us style borders.  default colour palette orange map classification ‘pretty’. can change next.
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_polygons(col = "percent",                title = "% registered") tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_fill(col = "percent", title = "% registered")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: tmap uses colour palettes ColorBrewer website differ depending chosen sequential, diverging, categorical colour scheme. wanted show birth registration values spread around mean use colour palettes diverging scheme. However, use palette sequential colour scheme want visual distribution values low high. use “Blues” palette visualises low values light blue high values dark blue.
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent",           palette = "Blues",           title = "% registered")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: map classification breaks set explicitly tmap defaults style = "pretty". base R function calculates roughly equal spaced round values. However, tmap number map classification schemes choose .

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Divides distribution values range values identical within class. difference highest lowest value class grouping. + represents density observations around mean- maps tend unbalanced values aren’t evenly distributed.
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent",           style = "equal",           n = 4,           palette = "Blues",           title = "% registered")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Sorts values variable ascending order assigns equal number geographical areas colour. + highlights proportion observations top 25% geographical areas- tends mask heterogeneity
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent",           style = "quantile",           n = 4,           palette = "Blues",           title = "% registered")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Class categories based natural groupings data. Uses statistical procedure seeks reduce variance within classes maximises variance classes. + identifies areas similar values- classes unique variable reused variables
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent",           style = "jenks",           n = 4,           palette = "Blues",           title = "% registered")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: Custom map classifications can created supplying breaks labels tm_fill() function.
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent",           breaks = c(0,40,58,76,Inf),           palette = "Blues",           labels = c(" < 40%", " 40 - 58%", " 58 - 76%", " > 76%"),           title = "Total registered")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: several improvements can make choropleth map changing layout, adding titles tweaking legend.  can also add cartographic elements compass rose (tm_compass()) scale bar (tm_scale_bar()) required.
code: tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#FFFFFF", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.6, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent", title = "% registered", style = "jenks", n = 4, palette = "Blues") +    tm_layout(frame = FALSE,             main.title = "Levels of birth registration in Nigeria",             main.title.size = 1.2,             legend.outside = TRUE) +   tm_credits("Source: MICS, 2021",               bg.color = "white",              position = c("right", "bottom"))

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: tmap package also allows view maps interactively. need switch tmap_mode("view") interactive viewing tmap_mode("plot") static plots. can change transparency colour fill changing alpha argument tm_fill() viewing interactively.
code: tmap_mode("view")

title: Creating choropleth maps
text: export static maps can use tmap_save() function. Just save plot object give filename.
code: tm <- tm_shape(sf) +    tm_borders(col = "#000000", lwd = 0.5) +   tm_text("state", size = 0.8, col = "black", auto.placement = TRUE) +   tm_fill(col = "percent",  style = "jenks", n = 4, palette = "Blues", title = "% registered", alpha = 0.3)  tmap_save(tm, filename = "nigeria.png")

title: Data cleaning
text: Dates can inputted variety formats “1 August 24”, Aug 1, 2024”, “2024-08-01”. Sometimes R able parse date read character. variable birth1a (Date occurrence, Event) character date. can coerce date passing .Date() function choosing corresponding date format. birth1a follows ISO 8601 standard dates ‘YYYY-MM-DD’ need format data “%Y-%m-%d”. Date formats R can also use ymd() function intuitively transforms date year, month, day.
code: df <- mutate(df, birth1a = as.Date(birth1a, format = "%Y-%m-%d")) class(df$birth1a) #> [1] "Date" mutate(df, birth1a = ymd(birth1a))

title: Data cleaning
text: may inputting errors civil registration data birth1a (Date occurrence, Event) recorded birth1b (Date registration, Event). identify records sync can use simple filter. code selects rows birth1a (Date occurrence, Event) birth1b (Date registration, Event) prints selected columns. can see registration dates entered “1900-01-01”.

title: Data cleaning
text: can identify duplicate rows using id variable unique. code groups data id filters one row. id variable present data create unique identifier concatenating one values. achieved join() function.
code: df |>    group_by(id) |>    filter(n()>1) #> # A tibble: 5 × 9 #> # Groups:   id [1] #>      id birth1a    birth1b    birth1c birth1g    birth1h birth1i birth2a birth3b #>   <int> <date>     <date>     <chr>   <chr>      <chr>   <chr>   <chr>     <int> #> 1   173 2024-07-08 2024-08-03 ""      Quadruple… Doctor  Hospit… F            85 #> 2   173 2024-07-08 2024-08-03 ""      Quadruple… Doctor  Hospit… F            85 #> 3   173 2024-07-08 2024-08-03 ""      Quadruple… Doctor  Hospit… F            85 #> 4   173 2024-07-08 2024-08-03 ""      Quadruple… Doctor  Hospit… F            85 #> 5   173 2024-07-08 2024-08-03 ""      Quadruple… Doctor  Hospit… F            85

title: Data cleaning
text: common practice read known values variable characters, hence stringsAsFactors = FALSE. However, read data may wish convert character variable factor. converting birth1g (Type birth, Event) factor.
code: class(df$birth1g) #> [1] "character" df$birth1g <- as_factor(df$birth1g) class(df$birth1g) #> [1] "factor"

title: Data cleaning
text: Sometimes order levels factor variable helpful. fct_relevel() function allows customise order levels. reorder values birth1g (Type birth, Event) “Single” comes first, “Twin” etc.
code: df$birth1g |> levels() #> [1] "Quadruplet or higher" "Twin"                 "Triplet"              #> [4] "Single" df$birth1g |> fct_relevel("Single", "Twin", "Triplet", "Quadruplet or higher") |> levels() #> [1] "Single"               "Twin"                 "Triplet"              #> [4] "Quadruplet or higher"

title: Data cleaning
text: Often values variable coded unhelpfully. example, birth2a (Sex, Newborn) sex newborn baby recorded “M” “F”. can easily recode readable. fct_recode() function enables change factor levels hand.
code: df$birth2a |>    fct_recode(Female = "F", Male = "M") |>    levels() #> [1] "Female" "Male"

title: Data cleaning
text: Missing values recorded variety ways e.g. 999999, NULL, even ” “. can recode missing values explicit NA using na_if() function. variable birth1c (Place occurrence, Event) includes number missing values recorded ” “. can replace NA using code .
code: df <- mutate(df, birth1c = na_if(birth1c, ""))

title: Data cleaning
text: identify many missing values whole dataset can run: 33 NA values birth1c (Place occurrence, Event) 10 birth3b (Age, Mother).
code: df |> map_dbl(~sum(is.na(.))) #>      id birth1a birth1b birth1c birth1g birth1h birth1i birth2a birth3b  #>       0       0       0      33       0       0       0       0      10

title: Data cleaning
text: cases missing values integer variable can impute average. example, 10 missing values birth3b (Age, Mother). can impute mean age following code.
code: df <- df |>    mutate(birth3b = case_when(     is.na(birth3b) ~ as.integer(mean(birth3b, na.rm = TRUE)),     TRUE ~ birth3b)     )

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: formatting styling table good idea understand structure syntax gt table. important functions gt package named relate parts table.  Table header: title subtitle Stub Stub Head: area left table containing row labels. stubhead contains label describes rows. Column labels: column labels Spanner column labels: labels grouped columns Table body: columns rows Table footer: text bottom table containing optional footnotes source notes

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: summary data Table 3.11 (Redistribution births incomplete data ‘age mother’, year) Vital Strategies report template.

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: default gt table can created using gt() function. simple table 4 columns.
code: df |> gt()

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: Stubs table row labels. can specify stub column using gt() function rowname_col argument. supplied ‘fert_age_grp’ stub column fertility age group grouping variable. Normally stubhead remain unlabelled supply label text tab_stubhead(). NB tables need row labels can skip step unnecessary. can also make additional styling improvements re-positioning stubhead label, formatting bold setting stub width. table now contains 3 columns assigned ‘fert_age_grp’ stub. wanted combine particular rows can use tab_row_group() function. Suppose wanted create ‘40+’ group just supply vector relevant age groups rows argument tab_row_group().
code: tbl <- df |>    # create a column of row names   gt(rowname_col = "fert_age_grp") |>    # add a stubhead label   tab_stubhead(label = "Mothers' age group (years)") |>    # style stubhead label   tab_style(     style = cell_text(v_align  = "top", weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_stubhead()   ) |>   # set stub width   cols_width(fert_age_grp ~ px(100))  # show the table tbl tbl |>    tab_row_group(     label = "40+",     rows = c("40-44", "45-49", "50+")   ) |>    tab_row_group(     label = "Under 40",     rows = 1:6   ) |>    tab_style(     style = cell_text(weight = "bold", style = "italic"),     locations = cells_row_groups()     )

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: customise column labels can use cols_label() function.
code: tbl <- tbl |>    cols_label(     total = "Number of births",     proportion = "Proportion (%)",     adjusted_total = "Number of births"   )  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: generic tab_style() function can used target column labels apply styling. use cells_column_labels() location helper function left-align format column labels bold.
code: tbl <- tbl |>    tab_style(     style = cell_text(align  = "right", weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_column_labels()   )  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: variety functions format column values. use fmt_number() specify whole numbers thousands separators ‘total’ ‘adjusted_total’ columns. function fmt_percent() converts values ‘proportion’ percentage one decimal place.
code: tbl <- tbl |>    fmt_number(columns = c("total", "adjusted_total"), decimals = 0) |>   fmt_percent(columns = "proportion", decimals = 1)  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: Grouping together columns can done tab_spanner() function. columns argument used specify columns span. can style spanner column labels using tab_style() cells_column_spanners() location helper function.
code: tbl <- tbl |>    tab_spanner(     label = "Unadjusted",     columns = c(total, proportion)   ) |>   tab_spanner(     label = "Adjusted",     columns = adjusted_total   ) |>    # style spanner column labels   tab_style(     style = cell_text(align  = "right", weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_column_spanners()   )  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: Add title subtitle table using tab_header() function. can style headings either markdown (md()) HTML (html()). used markdown format title bold. table headings centred default can change alignment either “left” “right” using opt_align_table_header() function.
code: tbl <- tbl |>    tab_header(     # style title using markdown     title = md("**Table 3.11**"),     subtitle = "Redistribution of live births with incomplete data on ‘age of mother’, year"   ) |>   # align left   opt_align_table_header(align = "left")  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: function tab_source_note() allows add source information table. possible style text either Markdown (md()) HTML (html()).
code: tbl <- tbl |>    tab_source_note(     source_note = md("*Source*: CRVS system")   )  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: Footnotes added gt tables using tab_footnote() function. consists two main arguments. provide text footnote using footnote target corresponding cells using location. footnote text can styled using md() html() cells can targeted using location helper function. example, supplied cells_column_spanners() location helper function tab_footnote() target particular spanner column label: ‘Adjusted’. can also customise set footnote marks using opt_footnote_marks() function. use ‘standard’ set asterisk, dagger, double dagger etc. can alternatively opt ‘numbers’, ‘letters’ even supply vector symbols using c().
code: tbl <- tbl |>    tab_footnote(     footnote = "Births were adjusted for missing values on age of mother",     locations = cells_column_spanners(spanners = "Adjusted")   ) |>    opt_footnote_marks(marks = "standard")  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: can use general purpose tab_style() function location helper functions style part table. format ‘Total’ cells_stub() row label bold. wanted draw attention specific value also highlight colour fill. locate target cell passing column name row number cells_body() location helper function tab_style(). Highlighting whole row require identifying relevant row.
code: tbl <- tbl |>    tab_style(     style = cell_text(weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_stub(rows = "Total")   )  # show the table tbl tbl |>    tab_style(     style = cell_fill(color = "tomato", alpha = 0.5),     locations = cells_body(columns = total, rows = 4)     ) tbl |>    tab_style(     style = cell_fill(color = "tomato", alpha = 0.5),     locations = cells_body(rows = fert_age_grp == "25-20")     )

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: can style whole table number ways. example, can use opt_table_font() function specify specific typeface. tab_options() function nearly 200 different styling options whole table. picked match table style Vital Strategies report template
code: tbl <- tbl |>    opt_table_font(font = google_font("Montserrat")) |>   tab_options(     # change size of text     heading.title.font.size = px(22),     heading.subtitle.font.size = px(18),     column_labels.font.size = px(15),     table.font.size = px(14),     # adjust table width     table.width = px(600),     # reduce the height of rows     data_row.padding = px(3),     # modify the table's background colour     table.background.color = "#EFF3F7",     # style borders     table.border.top.color = "transparent",     table.border.bottom.color = "transparent",     heading.border.bottom.color = "transparent",     column_labels.border.bottom.color = "#AFC3D8",     table_body.border.bottom.color = "#AFC3D8",     table_body.hlines.color = "#AFC3D8"   )  # show the table tbl

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: theme function applies consistent table styling options table. can applied :
code: theme_vs <- function(tbl) {   tbl |>      opt_table_font(font = google_font("Montserrat")) |>     tab_options(       heading.title.font.size = px(22),       heading.subtitle.font.size = px(18),       column_labels.font.size = px(15),       table.font.size = px(14),       table.width = px(600),       data_row.padding = px(3),       table.background.color = "#EFF3F7",       table.border.top.color = "transparent",       table.border.bottom.color = "transparent",       heading.border.bottom.color = "transparent",       column_labels.border.bottom.color = "#AFC3D8",       table_body.border.bottom.color = "#AFC3D8",       table_body.hlines.color = "#AFC3D8"       ) } tbl |>    theme_vs()

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: can combine different parts code together.
code: tbl <- df |>    # Rows   gt(rowname_col = "fert_age_grp") |>    tab_stubhead(label = "Mothers' age group (years)") |>    tab_style(     style = cell_text(v_align  = "top", weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_stubhead()   ) |>   cols_width(fert_age_grp ~ px(100)) |>    # Label columns   cols_label(     total = "Number of births",     proportion = "Proportion (%)",     adjusted_total = "Number of births"   ) |>    # Style column labels   tab_style(     style = cell_text(align  = "right", weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_column_labels()   ) |>    # Format columns   fmt_number(columns = c("total", "adjusted_total"), decimals = 0) |>   fmt_percent(columns = "proportion", decimals = 1) |>    # Spanner column labels   tab_spanner(     label = "Unadjusted",     columns = c(total, proportion)   ) |>   tab_spanner(     label = "Adjusted",     columns = adjusted_total   ) |>    tab_style(     style = cell_text(align  = "right", weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_column_spanners()   ) |>    # Headers   tab_header(     title = md("**Table 3.11**"),     subtitle = "Redistribution of live births with incomplete data on ‘age of mother’, year"   ) |>   opt_align_table_header(align = "left") |>    # Source notes   tab_source_note(     source_note = md("*Source*: CRVS system")   ) |>    # Footnotes   tab_footnote(     footnote = "Births were adjusted for missing values on age of mother",     locations = cells_column_spanners(spanners = "Adjusted")   ) |>    opt_footnote_marks(marks = "standard") |>    # Cell styling   tab_style(     style = cell_text(weight = "bold"),     locations = cells_stub(rows = "Total")   ) |>    # Table styling   vs_theme()

title: Creating publication-ready tables
text: happy table can export . gt provide number different output options including Word PDF. NB want export editable table (rather image) Word document run gtsave("gt_table_3_11.rtf").
code: # to a PNG tbl |> gtsave("gt_table_3_11.png", expand = 10)  # to a Word doc tbl |> gtsave("gt_table_3_11.docx")  # to a PDF tbl |> gtsave("gt_table_3_11.pdf")
